name: Dave
comment info:
Nowhere bear 170K would die if restrictions were lifted in April.  Why?
1. 50% of population (160M) have at least 1 shot.  120M fully vaccinated. 

2. Most vulnerable have been able to get vaccine for over a month.  84% 65+ had at least 1 dose

3. At least 160M already had/recovered (natural immunity). (32M "confirmed x 5 to account for untested=160M)

If you account for the fact that approx 1/3 of those w/natural immunity will get vaccine anyway that leaves an extra 110M to add to 160M vaccinated.

4. 110M+160M=270M which is approximately 82% of the U.S. population w/some form of immunity.
Even if you only use fully vaccinated it's 110M+120M = 230M which is  70%

5. The remaining unvaccinated people are "primarily" low risk people (or those who simply "choose" not to get vaccinated).  The death rate is ~0.03% for people "under" 60 (including the at-risk people).  After removing at-risk people from the data (because they've mostly been vaccinated) it reduces the death rate for the remaining "healthy" group to below 0.003%  (Yes, it's true.  Vaccinate the at-risk and you have a lot of "LOW RISK" people leftover.  Should be common sense).

That means 58M x .003%= 1,740K of those "healthy" people could die (NOT 170K).  Look at the CDC data per age groups and account for removing at-risk groups...

You're Welcome
Respect Logic/INTP's

https: //covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations
https: //www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/how-covid-spreads.html

name: msprinker
comment info:
These graphs make one assumption which is yet to be proven - that being infected with SARS-CoV-2 and recovering makes one immune for at least 1 year (first cases in early 2020).  The scenarios imply that roughly 35% of the population has been infected by mid-February 2021.  Given that the majority of those will have had no symptoms (asymptomatic) of or mild symptoms, you are suggesting that those folks will be immune.

We do not yet know the amount of antibodies and T-cells, etc., required to impart immunity.  SO the premise of this exercise would seem to have a glaring fault when predicting the date herd immunity will occur.

name: Lil
comment info:
Pt.3 

There are many concerns surrounding the virus, but I see the biggest as the prominent amount of uncertainty. Ever since the start of it all, the public has been left with lingering questions upon when life will become normal again. The reveal helped me understand many parts of the article more clearly. At first, I was unaware of the difference that threshold immunity had compared to vaccine immunity. Many people, mostly between Democrats and Republicans, argued over the act of removing masks and what it could bring our country. I was unaware that threshold immunity is much more harmful than immunity formed by vaccines. It is only after a person receives both shots of the vaccines when they are announced fully vaccinated. This ultimately slows down the whole process of distributing vaccines, making it take much longer to reach the longed for threshold. After reading more information within the article, I also saw how total immunity includes the estimated number of those who contracted the virus and recovered from it. Even with the total immunity reaching its threshold in every chart, the deaths that will simultaneously occur are always much higher. This creates an inquiry for researchers of which plan is the most efficient way to take on the virus without too much hurt to the public.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Lil You definitely summarized it greatly!

name: Lil
comment info:
Pt.1
More Restrictions Or Less Limitations. What Is The Right Call?
Once I reviewed the graphs detailed in this article, I noticed how obvious it is that Graph B is the most feasible and secure solution in order to reach the wanted herd immunity. Saying this, is this even an achievable plan? Even with President Biden's vision of having every adult in the United States vaccinated by May, many states lifted mask rules which could possibly set us back. Then again, is this act perhaps a step in a positive direction? Many debates are forming around this topic and the answer is unclear whether or not this risky move was beneficial. With disregard to the newly mask-less states, I can still see Biden's goal upon vaccines being reached. Teens, the most populated group of virus spreaders, are a huge factor to our goals. The vaccines are unable to cater to anyone under 16, leaving a vast portion of teens without the ability to get one. Even people the age of 16 who are eligible for the vaccine still have questions about it's safety. Will there be significant side effects that could possibly scare away many teens from receiving the vaccine? There are many concerns that I have, especially with Graph B and how it shows 90,000 casualties occurring if we are to reach immunity. It's also known in Graph D how unenlightened the United States is due to the possibility of new contagious variants springing up out of nowhere. How will scientists become aware of a new variant once it reaches us?

name: Lil
comment info:
Pt.2 

Even though it appears that most subjects relating to the virus are estimated, it's difficult to understand the need for restrictions or not. This could potentially shut down North Carolina this summer if the spread becomes too out of control. Other North Western states will likely not have to deal with this possibility. Beaches could be closed along with restaurants, hurting our community even more due to all of the “mask-free” visirots. The decision to live by these seemingly necessary rules is a very poor decision in my eyes. Even when a state has low infection numbers, it's hard to manage travelers once Summer is here.

name: Sarah (Fourth Block)
comment info:
PART 1

More Restrictions Or Less Limitations. What Is The Right Call?

After studying these four graphs closely, it is clear to see that Graph B is the safest and fastest solution to reach the ideal threshold. However, how practical is this scenario? Although President Biden has made a promise to have every U.S. adult vaccinated by the end of May, states such as Texas, Mississippi, Iowa, Montana, and North Dakota have lifted mask restrictions with their states. Is this a move in the right or wrong direction? Is this the light at the end of a dark tunnel or a move taken too soon? At the current rate, vaccines are being distributed, I do believe Biden will uphold his promise. But the next concern is teenagers, argued the biggest group of spreaders for the virus. Testing is happening to ensure teens over the age of sixteen are able to receive the vaccine safely, but how long might this take? How many parents will allow their children to become vaccinated if it has potentially side effects? My biggest concern with the charts in the uncertainty. Graph B states that we could reach the herd immunity threshold by May, but in that time, 90,000 people could die. There is no way of knowing whether more contagious variants as displayed in graph D should be a concern or whether we are immune to all strains once vaccinated.

replies.name: S

name: Eppy Camacho (3rd Block)
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
In my original response, I hit the mark in my discussion of how less precautions meant quicker immunity but more death, and that there is going to be a lot of deaths no matter which scenario plays out. I also noted that the immunity totals could very possibly be less than indicated because I know people who have had it twice. I failed to really analyze the other graphs and compare them to each other. Originally, I didn't even notice that the vaccine threshold is never reached in the variant scenario(Graph D).

After reading the reveal, I see that the graphs represent not only vaccine immunity, meaning the number of people who have been fully vaccinated, but also a total immunity including both vaccinated and those recovered from Covid-19. Each graph predicts when the immunity threshold will be met in four different circumstances. The first graph (Graph A) predicts that we will reach total immunity in July, and vaccine immunity in November if the country continues to handle the virus as it currently is, keeping restrictions and a steady vaccine rollout. This model predicts that 100,000 people could die from the virus before the herd immunity threshold is met in July. Graph B shows a prediction that we will reach total immunity in May, and the vaccine immunity threshold in July if we stay the same other than nearly doubling the vaccine rollout, from 1.7 million to 3 million shots per day. (I will reply to this comment with the rest)

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: After reading more about the graphs I have a better understanding of what they mean. With so many factors that go into stopping this pandemic it is certain that there is going to be a large number of deaths. First off we can see in graph A that maintaining our current pace isn’t a bad option, but if we performed graph B and gave more shots everyday we would be able to reach herd immunity by May. There are also two options that would create more havoc, graph C and D. Graph C would allow us to lessen up on restrictions before we hit herd immunity which would cause us to have a massive surge in deaths and cases. Graph D would also cause problems because if variants of the virus are created and we don’t have an adequate way to deal with them the situation will just get worse. Both option C and D will push back progression and force us to reach herd immunity way longer than if we all worked together and tried to complete graph B. The threshold of reaching graph immunity is between 70 and 90 percent. A big factor of how fast we reach this is how many vaccinations are given everyday. At our current pace(graph A) 100,00 will die and herd immunity will be reached in July.  If we increased the amount of shots to 3 million we could reach herd immunity by May and 90,000  could die. If we were somehow able to increase our output to 5 million shots we would reach herd immunity in April and 80,00 could die. If we want to save as many lives we need to increase shots and go with graph B.

replies.name: L
replies.comment info:
@Lauren Durham Block 4 In re-reading my initial post, I'm surprised to realize that many others have the same wonders that I do. And like me, they also don't know the answers to questions such as how long the vaccines will be effective / how long the antibodies remain after infection. Something that I did not consider was that easing up restrictions could point to earlier herd immunity, but could also increase the probability of a mutated strand that would set us back to square one.
The ideal situation is if vaccinations are severely increased. This results in the quickest total and herd immunities while also having the lowest death rate. On the other hand, with increased vaccinations there will be more temptation to lift restrictions. By lifting restrictions, the time until vaccine immunity is not altered very much, but the total immunity suffers greatly. There is also a bigger chance for mutations and increased death rates. So all in all, it is best to increase vaccinations while keeping measures in place. Unfortunately, this is not realistic. The more likely situation involves a steady or slightly increased vaccine dosage with safety measures either kept in place or loosened.

name: Anonymous (Student Block 1),
comment info:
After studying these graphs, it’s apparent that there's no situation where deaths are completely preventable; they're going to occur regardless of the path we take. That being said, at first glance, Graph B seems to provide the best course of action. It shows that we could reach herd immunity by May, the earliest of all the predicted months, and estimates the least amount of potential deaths (~90,000). However, looking closer at this graph, I wonder at its probability/reality. It says in order to achieve these results, we would have to increase the supply of vaccines to 3 million per day, immediately. That’s nearly double what our current supply is (1.7 M), something that seems difficult to achieve promptly. As far as the impact these graphs and their trajectories have on my community and me, I’d say that Graph A, our current proceedings, seems most beneficial and would be the one I’d encourage us to stick with. I know everyone is anxious for things to return to normal, believe me, I am too, but when weighing the different aspects of each respective graph (timeframe, amount of potential deaths, the feasibility of actions), Graph A seems to provide the best balance. Compared to Graphs C and D, it has fewer deaths while also seeming more plausible than Graph B. The expected herd immunity of Graph A is reached in July, just like Graph D, but predicts fewer deaths than that graph.

comment info:
The graphs shown are showing the time it will take to herd immunity for the Coronavirus in the US. Herd Immunity means 70% – 90% of people are immune to the virus, whether through getting vaccinated or becoming infected and creating a natural immunity. Descriptions of what each graph is showing: 
Graph A: Current supply of vaccinations and public precautions
Graph B: Increasing the vaccine supply and maintaining public precautions
Graph C: Maintaining the vaccine supply with lifting some public precautions in the spring
Graph D: Maintaining vaccine supply and public precautions, but experiencing contagious variants 
All four of these graphs present different situations in which herd immunity is speculated to reach the 70%-90% mark. 
Graph B has the “most effective” situation. This scenario is upping the vaccine distribution count to 3 million shots per day instead of the 1.7 million in Graphs A, C, and D. It has the fewest deaths, 90,000, out of all four graphs. This graph also shows that the herd of immunity would most likely be reached by May. Graph D on the other hand is the “least effective” out of the four graphs. This scenario is saying that a more contagious variant will spread faster, therefore upping the herd of immunity. This graph is predicting the most deaths, 200,000, compared to the lower death toll of graphs A, B, and C. This graph is foreseeing the herd of immunity to be reached by July. I feel that a catchy title could be, "Herd Immunity: Now or Never?"

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graphs show the results of a model that estimates when the U.S. will obtain herd immunity from the coronavirus.  (Herd immunity occurs when enough people become immunity to a disease to make its spread unlikely.  This is a result of vaccinations and natural infection.)   Here are graphs for four situations:  under current conditions, with increased supply of vaccines, with relaxing social distancing, and with more contagious variant spreads. 

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “What impact does this topic have on you and your community?”

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

View our archives that link to past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).

name: Paul Coffield
comment info:
I notice that the four graphs represent four possible ways in which the United States could reach herd immunity. The first graph shows what the future could look like if we continue with life as it is now: 1.7 million vaccinations a day with public precautions (social distancing and mask-wearing). The second graph shows a future in which 3 million vaccinations are given per day. In this possible scenario, we would reach herd immunity by May. The third graph shows what the future would look like if we continue with 1 million vaccinations a day, and then lift the restrictions in April. In this scenario, we would reach herd immunity faster, but with more deaths. The final example shows a future in which a more contagious variant spreads. In this scenario, it would take until July to reach herd immunity and up to 200,000 more people could die from the virus.

I wonder which scenario is most likely. I also wonder if the government plans on increasing their vaccination rates to 3 million shots per day, like in the second graph. I wonder if a more contagious variant has already begun to spread throughout the U.S. Finally, I wonder what exactly herd immunity entails. Does herd immunity mean that the virus vanishes completely?

This impacts my community because vaccinations mean less deaths and a return to normal life in my community. Covid 19 is abundant in my city and increased vaccination rates would help us all greatly.

Headline: Four Paths to the Normal World—But at What Cost?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Paul Coffield --

You wonder which scenario is most likely.  With three vaccines now, isn’t it up to the public and policymakers which scenario would be used?

You ask about herd immunity.  No, it does not mean that the virus will vanish.  But, it does mean that it is less unlikely that it will spread.  Think about what 70% or more immunity nationally could look like in the U.S.  Would the other 30% or less be spread throughout the country?  Mostly in specific regions?  Among specific groups of people?

name: Chiara Salvati
comment info: These graphs represent the various possibilities and scenarios of vaccines, public precautions and variants of the virus.  The first graph shows the current situation where there are no variants and with the current number of vaccines the immunity threshold would be reached in July but in the meantime 100,000 people could die. The second graph illustrates the potential situation of an increase of 3 million vaccines always without variants you could reach the immunity threshold in May with 10,000 deaths. As for the third graph, it shows how with a loosening of the precautions during the spring and with the same dose of vaccines at this time we could reach the immunity threshold in June, however with 170,000 deaths. Finally, the last graph proposes a situation where variations of the virus increase with the same number of vaccines and taking into account public precautions. In this case, the immunity threshold would be reached in June but there would be twice the number of deaths compared to the current situation. In our opinion, the best option is illustrated in the second graph because we would reach faster the immunity threshold and less people would die.
